title: Humanistic rhetoric became a rival to Aristotelian rationalism, especially after the posthumous publication of the Disputationes dialecticae of the Frisian humanist Rudolf Agricola in 1515

container-title: Rodolphus Agricola Phrisius, 1444–1485
note: The principal study is Walter J.
title: Renaissance Argument: Valla and Agricola in the Traditions of Rhetoric and Dialectic
The rhetoricians rarely attacked Aristotle’s authority directly, but Aristotle did come under direct attack by the influential French philosopher Peter Ramus
Method, and the Decay of Dialogue

container-title: Renaissance Concepts of Method
title: Other discussions of Ramus and rhetoric are Wilbur Samuel Howell, Logic and Rhetoric in England, 1500–1700

note: is the definitive work. See also Luciano Floridi, Sextus Empiricus: The Transmission
title: The History of Scepticism from Erasmus to Descartes

note: Although Rabelais was no sceptic, he referred to sceptical writers and delighted in paradox. See Barbara C. Bowen, The Age of 228 | the sixteenth century
title: On the Threshold of Modernity: Relativism in the French Renaissance

container-title: Handbook of European History, 1400–1600: Late Middle Ages, Renaissance, and Reformation
History of the Church
On the Reformation, there are multiple-author treatments in Andrew Pettegree (ed.), The Reformation World
The older composite
note: Carter Lindberg, The European Reformations (Oxford and Cambridge, Mass., 1996); more recently see the somewhat idiosyncratic but brilliant Owen Chadwick, The Early Reformation on the Continent (Oxford and New York: 2001) and the astonishingly wide-ranging and well-read Diarmaid MacCulloch, Reformation: Europe’s House Divided, 1490–1700 (London, 2004; American edn. The Reformation: A History, New York and London, 2004).
title: The Turmoil of Faith: Euan Cameron The transition from late Middle Ages to Renaissance and Reformation has received a powerful full-dress treatment by an array of authorities in Thomas A

For religion see especially the essays by Scribner and Van Engen in vol. i, and all of parts 1 and 2 of vol. ii. A still excellent and much shorter introduction is Steven Ozment, The Age of Reform 1250–1550: An Intellectual and Religious History of Late Medieval and Reformation Europe (New Haven, 1980
suffers from its overtly pro-Catholic stance and also from its age
A Companion to the Reformation World
There are also single-author essays by Euan Cameron, The European Reformation
Popular belief before and during the Reformation era still awaits a fully definitive survey, such are the problems both of evidence and of method
Religion and the Decline of Magic: Studies in Popular Beliefs in Sixteenth and Seventeenth Century England

despite its age and being rather heavily influenced by post-Reformation Protestant sources, remains remarkably cogent. From an avowedly apologetic Catholic perspective is the brilliant but partisan Eamon further reading | 229

note: R. W. Scribner, Popular Culture and Popular Movements in Reformation Germany (London and Ronceverte, WV, 1988), contains some excellent essays on this topic.
title: Local Religion in Sixteenth-Century Spain
The Religions of the People in Sixteenth-Century Champagne
and perhaps most exciting of all David Gentilcore, From Bishop to Witch: The System of the Sacred in Early Modern Terra d’Otranto

container-title: The Western Church in the Later Middle Ages (Ithaca, NY, and London, 1979), as is Robert Swanson, Religion and Devotion in Europe, c.1215–c.1515
note: Preaching is ably discussed in Larissa Taylor, Soldiers of Christ: Preaching in Late Medieval and Reformation France
title: The Magical Universe: Everyday Ritual and Magic in Pre-Modern Europe

suffers from a lack of chronological and regional specificity and a poverty of theoretical reflection, though the information contained in it is copious. On the Church before the Reformation a still excellent survey is Francis Oakley

note: Thomas N. Tentler, Sin and Confession on the Eve of the Reformation
title: while the Eucharist is well treated in Miri Rubin, Corpus Christi: The Eucharist in Late Medieval Culture

note: David Myers, ‘Poor, Sinning Folk’: Confession and Conscience in Counter-Reformation Germany
title: remains a fine study of confessional theory and practice, though needing to be supplemented by the work of W

note: Scribner, For the Sake of Simple Folk: Popular Propaganda for the German Reformation (Cambridge and New York: Cambridge University Press, 1981; also later edn., Oxford and New York, 1994) pioneered this subject in English; noteworthy are Mark 230 | the sixteenth century
title: Preaching and the Coming of the Reformation

Popes and Princes, 1417–1517: Politics and Polity in the Late Medieval Church (London and Boston, 1980) offers a balanced and fair appraisal of the pre-Reformation papacy. Martin Luther has probably received more biographies than anyone in history other than major political leaders. Out of hundreds the historian needs chiefly the balanced and careful Martin Brecht, Martin Luther, tr
the definitive modern biography, and the whimsical but ever-brilliant Heiko A
Some important works study the transmission of the Reformation message through pamphlet and printed image
The Rhetoric of the Reformation

note: New Haven, 1975) remains valid if overstated. Also still worthwhile is Bernd Moeller, Imperial Cities and the Reformation: Three Essays,
title: The hitherto vast literature on the reception of the Reformation in the cities of Europe has thinned out considerably in recent years (paradoxically as the amount of synthetic and evaluative material has increased). The now classic introductory essay by A
still offers accessible summaries of older monograph literature
The Reformation in the Cities: The Appeal of Protestantism to Sixteenth-Century Germany and Switzerland
Edwards, jun

container-title: and Lee Palmer Wandel, Voracious Idols and Violent Hands: Iconoclasm in Reformation Zurich
location: Strasbourg, and Basel (Cambridge and New York
title: Turning Swiss: Cities and Empire, 1450–1550

while conceptually sophisticated, is very hard on the non-specialist reader. Among many local studies noteworthy are Lorna Jane Abray, The People’s Reformation: Magistrates, Clergy, and Commons in Strasbourg, 1500–1598
Zwickau in Transition, 1500–1547: The Reformation as an Agent of Change

container-title: The Reformation of the Parishes: The Ministry and the Reformation in Town and Country
note: Some fine regional studies include C. Scott Dixon, The Reformation and Rural Society: The Parishes of Brandenburg-Ansbach-Kulmbach, 1528–1603
title: A fruitful genre of historical writing on the Reformation has focused on the implementation of reforming measures at the parish level, including worship and discipline as well as the inculcation of doctrine. A good collection of essays on this topic is
Pastors and Parishioners in Württemberg during the late Reformation, 1581–1621
For Germanspeaking Swiss territories a fine general introduction is Bruce Gordon, The Swiss Reformation
An interesting interpretation of the cultural changes is afforded by Susan Karant-Nunn, The Reformation of Ritual: An Interpretation of Early Modern Germany

The evergreen subject of the peasant movements of the 1520s is now dominated, if not quite entirely, by the seminal study of Peter Blickle, The Revolution of 1525: The German Peasants’ War from a New Perspective, tr

container-title: Historical Journal
note: and on Tom Scott and Robert W. Scribner further reading | 231

note: R. Po-chia Hsia, The World of Catholic Renewal, 1540–1770,

note: Bakewell, Silver Mining and Society in Colonial Mexico (Cambridge, 1971) is still pertinent. On Peru James Lockhart, Spanish Peru 1532–1560 (Madison, 1968),

Madison, 1982), and Peter J. Bakewell, Miners of the Red Mountain (Albuquerque, 1984) cover colonial society and economy. Charles R. Boxer, The Portuguese Seaborne Empire 1415–1825 (London, 1969) offers a good introduction. Sanjay Subrahmanyam, The Portuguese Empire in Asia, 1500–1700 (London, 1993) is essential, but can be enlarged by Bailey W. Diffie and George W. Winius, Foundations of the Portuguese Empire 1415–1580
title: On the Spanish conquerors, James Lockhart, The Men of Cajamarca
defines the demographic catastrophe. On Las Casas and subsequent historiography D
The First America: The Spanish Monarchy, Creole Patriots, and the Liberal State 1492–1867
is comprehensive. James Lockhart, The Nahuas after the Conquest
is innovative and masterly
Peru’s Indian Peoples and the Challenge of Spanish Conquest

title: Portuguese Trade in Asia and the Habsburgs, 1580–1640

title: whose title says all
is still indispensable. On Africa there is John Thornton, Africa and Africans in the Making of the Atlantic World

The Making of New World Slavery

container-title: follows the Portuguese and Jesuits in Ethiopia. Stephen Neill, A History of Christianity in India: The Beginnings to AD 1707
note: traces the story of the St Thomas Christians.
title: Art on the Jesuit Missions in Asia and Latin America 1542–1773
covers much more than art. Adrian Hastings, The Church in Africa 1450–1950

note: Medici rule restored in Florence.
title: Confession of Augsburg and Tetrapolitan Confession presented by Lutheran and south German reformers respectively. François appoints first royal lecturers, beginnings of Collège Royal
Founding of the Protestant League of Schmalkalden, led by the Lutheran princes and cities. Battle of Kappel and death of Huldrych Zwingli
Publication of first (posthumous) edition of Machiavelli’s The Prince. Publication of first edition of François Rabelais’s Pantagruel
John Calvin flees from France to Basel after associating with reformers. 238 | the sixteenth century
Bernardino Ochino to the Reformation; Roman Inquisition established
First edition of Copernicus, On the Revolutions of the Heavenly Spheres, published
Council of Trent opens
War breaks out between Charles V and League of Schmalkalden

container-title: Death of Henry
note: accession of Edward VI as king of England.
title: Battle of Mühlberg: Charles V defeats League of Schmalkalden. Council of Trent transferred to Bologna and session closed. Death of Francis I; accession of Henri II as king of France

note: Lutherans divided in their responses to the Interim.
title: Iron-clad’ Reichstag at Augsburg: Charles V issues the Interim settlement of religion for Germany
Zürich consensus’ establishes theological accord between Zürich and Geneva. Many continental Protestant theologians settle in England; first Book of Common Prayer issued

author.literal: Giammaria Ciocchi del Monte elected Pope as Julius III.

title: Debate organized at Valladolid between Las Casas and Juan Ginés de SepúIveda about morality of Spanish conquest of New World and treatment of its peoples
Council of Trent begins its second phase of deliberations. Henri II of France and Duke Moritz of Saxony make Lochau Heath agreement to attack Emperor Charles V

author.literal: V; Henri II seizes Metz, Toul, and Verdun

container-title: Closure of second phase of Council of Trent. Second Book of Common Prayer issued in England. Francisco López de Gómara publishes Historia General de las Indias
title: Princes’ War’ in Germany: Duke Moritz attacks Charles
Peace of Passau ends the fighting
Death of Edward VI; accession of Mary I as queen of England; re-establishment of Catholic worship and exile of foreign Protestants
England restored to communion with the Roman Catholic Church. 240 | the sixteenth century
Belgic Confession’ prepared by reformed churches of the Netherlands
Massacre at Vassy begins first phase of French Wars of Religion. Council of Trent enters third and final phase

note: Death of Ferdinand I: Maximilian II elected Holy Roman Emperor. Decrees of the Council of Trent promulgated and published.
title: Council of Trent closes its final session. chronology | 241 Heidelberg Confession issued for reformed church in Electoral Palatinate. First version of Thirty-Nine Articles of Religion adopted in England. 1564 Death of Calvin

publisher: Knights of St John defeat Ottomans at Malta
title: Death of Pope Pius IV

author.literal: Michele Ghislieri elected pope as Pius V. Roman Catechism issued.

container-title: Death of Sultan Suleiman I of the Ottoman Empire
title: Hedge-preaching’ and iconoclasm in the Low Countries bring the conflict over Protestantism there to a head. Second Helvetic Confession adopted by Swiss reformed churches
Council of Troubles set up in Netherlands by Spanish military regime under duke of Alva to suppress the rebellion
1568 Spanish ambush of John Hawkins’s and Francis Drake’s ships in San Juan de Ulúa. Counts Egmont and Hoorn executed in Brussels by Spanish regime
Revolt of the (Catholic) ‘northern earls’ against Elizabeth I. Union of Lublin unites Poland with Lithuania as a Commonwealth
Pope Pius V declares Elizabeth I of England excommunicate and deposed. Consensus of Sandomierz unites the Trinitarian Protestants of Poland in a joint agreement against the Unitarians
Holy Alliance defeats Ottoman Empire in sea-battle at Lepanto. Definitive version of Thirty-Nine Articles adopted for Church of England

container-title: Dutch Revolt breaks out afresh in Holland and Zealand
title: Marriage of Henri de Navarre and Marguerite de Valois; massacre of St Bartholomew follows in Paris and other cities
François Hotman’s Francogallia first published. 242 | the sixteenth century

note: Ottomans reconquer Tunis, previously held by Don John of Austria.
title: Death of Charles IX; Henri III succeeds as king of France
Bohemian Confession’ establishes coexistence between non-Catholic churches in Bohemia. Philip II declares Spanish crown bankrupt for the third time

author.literal: Death of Maximilian II; Rudolf II succeeds as Holy Roman Emperor.

title: Peace of Monsieur offers French Protestants most favourable peace terms; enrages Catholics and prompts formation of the League. Sack of Antwerp by unpaid Spanish troops temporarily unites the Netherlands against Philip II’s rule

Formula of Concord agreed: reunites fractured elements of the Lutheran churches (Book of Concord embodying the agreement was published 1580). ‘Eternal Edict’ supposedly brings peace in the Netherlands but breaks down soon afterwards

container-title: Alessandro Farnese, duke of Parma
note: appointed Governor-General of the Netherlands.
title: Moors defeat Portuguese at battle of Al Kasr al Kebir (also Alcazarquivir) in North Africa: King Sebastian of Portugal killed, extinguishing the royal line

Union of Utrecht gives rudimentary form to the alliance of the states of the northern Netherlands in revolt against Philip II. 1580 Crown of Portugal passes to Spain. Montaigne’s Essais published. Francis Drake completes his circumnavigation of the world and returns to England with plunder from the Spanish empire
Northern provinces of the Netherlands renounce allegiance to Philip II
Gregorian calendar reform instituted, leading to a 10-day difference in dates between Catholic and Protestant countries
Catholic troops invade archbishopric of Cologne to remove a Protestant claimant to the see, threatening the religious peace in Germany

container-title: League makes Treaty of Joinville with Philip II of Spain. Assassination of William the Silent
note: leader of the Dutch Revolt.
title: Death of François duke of Anjou leaves the Valois line without heirs. chronology | 243 Catholic League established in France to prevent the succession to the throne of Henri de Navarre, a Protestant
War breaks out between England and Spain following alliance between Elizabeth I and Dutch Republic by the Treaty of Nonsuch. Duke of Parma captures Antwerp for Spain from Dutch rebels

container-title: English ships raid Spanish fleet in Cádiz
title: Elizabeth I’s government executes Mary Queen of Scots for conspiracy

1588 Spanish Armada sails against England but is attacked by English at battle of Gravelines and fails to land in England. Pope Sixtus V establishes ‘congregations’ of cardinals. Henri III orders the murders of the duke and cardinal of Guise

publisher: Giovanni Botero publishes Reason of State
title: Henri III of France assassinated: Henri de Navarre succeeds as Henri IV

container-title: José de Acosta publishes Historia Natural y Moral de las Indias
title: Pope Sixtus V issues defective revision of the Vulgate Latin Bible. Philip II raises new heavy domestic taxes for wartime expenses
After a series of short pontificates, Ippolito Aldobrandini elected as Pope Clement VIII. Clement VIII’s further revision of Sixtus V’s Vulgate issued
Henri IV of France declares his reconversion from Protestantism to Roman Catholicism

container-title: Earl of Tyrone’s rebellion breaks out in Ireland
title: Henri IV takes possession of Paris and is crowned king
Henri IV declares war on Spain over its continuing support for the League

note: Johannes Kepler publishes Mysterium Cosmographicum.
title: English raid against the Spanish fleet and fortifications at Cádiz. Philip II declares Spanish crown bankrupt for the fourth time

container-title: Death of Philip II; Philip III succeeds as king of Spain
note: Irish rebels defeat English forces at Yellow Ford.
title: Edict of Nantes imposes an end to religious conflict in France; grants partial toleration for reformed Church in the kingdom. 244 | the sixteenth century Peace of Vervins ends conflict between France and Spain
English troops defeat the Irish rebellion at Kinsale

note: Suppression of Irish rebellion.
title: Death of Elizabeth I of England; James VI of Scotland succeeds as James I
Treaty of London: peace agreed between England and Spain
Papacy places the republic of Venice under interdict
Seizure of Donauwörth by duke of Bavaria again threatens to destabilize the religious peace in Germany
Emperor Rudolf II forced to yield control over some of his territories to Matthias I

Twelve years’ truce declared in war between Dutch and Spain. Rival Protestant and Catholic Leagues formed in Germany. Disputed succession in duchies of Jülich-Cleves threatens religious conflict in Germany
Henri IV of France assassinated: Louis XIII succeeds as a minor

author.literal: Emperor Rudolf II deposed in favour of Matthias I.
